runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that a coding camp is a camp where children learn to write code for computers. Computer code is a language that gives instructions that computers can follow.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a feeling of being sure you can do something.
that Casey can solve the problem.
What is something you can do with
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names where Lucy likes to be. (outside)
in her ability to learn coding? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What makes Lucy confident that she will learn to code?
What is a skill that was hard for you to learn at first, but then you learned it? How did you get better at it?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that a simple machine is a machine that has a few or no moving parts. It makes objects easier for people to move.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means independent, or being able to depend on your own abilities.
, so he can live on his own.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what kind of machines Matt uses. (simple)
How do simple machines help us? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What machine helps to make Matt
? How does this machine help him be
What is a tool or simple machine that makes work easier for you? How does it help you?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with vowel-consonant
syllables. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Contrast sentences that make a statement with those that ask a question. For example, ask how sentence 1 is different than sentence 2. (Sentence 1 begins with the word
and ends with a period. Sentence 2 begins with the word
and ends with a question mark.)
Repeat by contrasting sentences 4 and 5, and 6 and 7. Then contrast questions 4, 6, 8, and 9 by focusing on the question word each starts with.
Read the title. Remind students that when the text is in the form of a comic strip, the speech bubbles show what the characters are saying.

For the first reading, you read Robs part and have students read Siss part. Then switch roles and repeat for the second reading. For other readings, have one partner read Robs part and the other read Siss part, then switch roles and repeat.
Prompt students to circle all the words with vowel-consonant
syllables in the speech bubbles. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word.
Explain that students will learn about the following simple machines: an inclined plane, a pulley, and a lever.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means to tow or drag something.
We used a cart to help us
What would you do if you had to
a big log across a yard?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes a plane that is slanted. (inclined)
What kind of simple machine can be used to
a car into a truck? Find the sentence that answers this question.
What kind of simple machine is shown in each picture in the playground on page 17?
How has a simple machine helped you complete a task? Tell how it helped.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with vowel-consonant
syllables. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Model how to phrase sentences into meaningful parts. For example, read sentences 3 and 4 by chunking each into two parts:
We went inside/at five oclock. We went inside/and got a candle.
Have students repeat, then phrase another sentence on their own.

Read the title. Explain that this text uses photos and a diagram to show how a pulley works. The author includes photos and diagrams to help readers understand both parts and processes. Labels make the information even clearer.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the photos and diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the photos and diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to the word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a lost necklace.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
to reach the book on the top shelf.
What is something hard that you
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what kind of tree Kate looked under. (maple)
When did Kate notice her necklace was missing? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How had Kate attempted to solve her problem?
What is something you lost? Did you ever find it? What happened?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students look at the picture.
Explain to students that the word
can sometimes describe something that feels slightly cold. Ask students to predict what they will learn in this story.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Have students whisper read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Which word tells what the man was selling in the booth next to the ice cream seller? (waffles)
Where was the man selling his ice cream? Find the sentence that answers the question.
that was not available for the man to sell ice cream?
Do you prefer to eat ice cream from a dish or cone? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
